<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BIG DEAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/17/revisiting-mlks-vision-universal-basic-income?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Why MLK and Andrew Yang Would've Been Pals
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="The Poor People's March on the National Mall " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc5MTg2MDA1LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Four years after delivering his “I Have a Dream Speech” in Washington D.C., Martin Luther King Jr. was at it again. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In 1967, King started <a href="https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/remembering-poor-peoples-campaign-180968742/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">planning</a> <em>another </em>march on the National Mall—but instead of focusing on racial inequality, this protest, known as the Poor People’s Campaign, would highlight economic inequality. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The demonstration he envisaged would involve constructing a tent city on the mall, where protesters would pressure Congress using nonviolent methods. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">King was assassinated weeks before he could see it through. But as he laid out his vision for the economy leading up to the event, King proposed an idea—shunned at the time but rising in popularity now—of a universal basic income (UBI). </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The vision </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">King was a frequent critic of the economic status quo. But because he was MLK, instead of writing things like “Capitalism is bad” he <a href="https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/king-papers/documents/notes-american-capitalism?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a> things like “Capitalism finds herself like a losing football team in the last quarter trying all types of tactics to survive.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On that note I'll take a step back and let King continue...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The contemporary tendency in our society is to base our distribution on scarcity, which has vanished, and to compress our abundance into the overfed mouths of the middle and upper classes until they gag with superfluity.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The curse of poverty has no justification in our age. It is socially as cruel and blind as the practice of cannibalism at the dawn of civilization…”</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So what was his solution?</strong> King focused on the <a href="https://www.thenation.com/article/dr-martin-luther-kings-economics-through-jobs-freedom/#axzz2dI11N39W?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">demand side</a>, writing “We must create full employment or we must create incomes...people must be made consumers by one method or the other.” </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>King believed that no amount of economic growth in a capitalist system would ensure everyone got a job. So he wanted the government to provide every American with a guaranteed middle-class income, one that would rise with the cost of living. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Bringing it to today</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Writing about King’s plan in The Atlantic in 2013, Jordan Weissmann <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2013/08/martin-luther-kings-economic-dream-a-guaranteed-income-for-all-americans/279147/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called</a> the idea of a basic income “light-years beyond the realm of mainstream political conversation today.”  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Seven light-years later, basic income has entered the mainstream political conversation, if you consider the sixth place candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination mainstream.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Entrepreneur Andrew Yang’s campaign boils down to one tweet:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1579218403.jpg" class="img-responsive" width="300" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The candidate’s main policy proposal is the <a href="https://freedom-dividend.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Freedom Dividend</a>, a basic income of $1,000/month for every American over 18. Yang’s reasoning for UBI is very different than King’s, though. He’s primarily concerned about the mass disruption to jobs caused by AI and automation as part of the “fourth industrial revolution.”   </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To be sure, UBI has more opponents in the U.S. than supporters. I’ll list just a few of the <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/100137b4-0cdf-11e8-bacb-2958fde95e5e?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">major criticisms</a> here…</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It’s too expensive</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>UBI would replace existing unemployment benefits and increase inequality</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>By separating work and income, it would warp social relationships</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>People would have less incentive to work</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It gives politicians a pass to sidestep tough future-of-work discussions</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a <a href="https://news.gallup.com/poll/267143/universal-basic-income-favored-canada-not.aspx?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Gallup poll</a> released last September, 43% of Americans said they supported a universal basic income program. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>UBI mini-experiments are happening all over the world, from <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/experiment-in-finland-with-guaranteed-income-creates-less-stress-but-no-jobs-11549650636?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Finland</a> to <a href="https://www.givedirectly.org/basic-income/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Kenya</a>. There’s no conclusive evidence yet, and some economists say any pilot study in an advanced country is <a href="https://www.nber.org/papers/w25538#fromrss?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doomed to fail</a>. But the fact that we’re even talking about it shows MLK’s little-known economic message is very much alive today. </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Reader question: </strong>When do you write Monday’s Morning Brew? Do you take turns with weekend assignments?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Neal’s answer: </strong>Well, I’m actually writing this on Thursday because it’s a special edition. Future Neal, I hope tonight’s date goes/went well. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But on normal weeks we write Monday’s Brew on Sunday, and yes, we do take turns. I usually like to wake up early on Sunday and write the newsletter in the morning, so I can spend the rest of the day losing money on football games. At night, we review the news again, write a little bit more if necessary, then go about the standard procedure of sending the Brew. Weekends are definitely slower for news, but typically there’s some big event on Monday to preview. For example, last Monday was the new Boeing CEO’s first day.</p>

width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc5MTg2MDA1LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGetty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFour years after delivering his “I Have a Dream Speech” in Washington D.C., Martin Luther King Jr. was at it again. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn 1967, King started \u003ca href=\"https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/remembering-poor-peoples-campaign-180968742/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eplanning\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eanother \u003c/em\u003emarch on the National Mall—but instead of focusing on racial inequality, this protest, known as the Poor People’s Campaign, would highlight economic inequality. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe demonstration he envisaged would involve constructing a tent city on the mall, where protesters would pressure Congress using nonviolent methods. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eKing was assassinated weeks before he could see it through. But as he laid out his vision for the economy leading up to the event, King proposed an idea—shunned at the time but rising in popularity now—of a universal basic income (UBI). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe vision \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eKing was a frequent critic of the economic status quo. But because he was MLK, instead of writing things like “Capitalism is bad” he \u003ca href=\"https://kinginstitute.stanford.edu/king-papers/documents/notes-american-capitalism?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e things like “Capitalism finds herself like a losing football team in the last quarter trying all types of tactics to survive.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn that note I'll take a step back and let King continue...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The contemporary tendency in our society is to base our distribution on scarcity, which has vanished, and to compress our abundance into the overfed mouths of the middle and upper classes until they gag with superfluity.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The curse of poverty has no justification in our age. It is socially as cruel and blind as the practice of cannibalism at the dawn of civilization…”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo what was his solution?\u003c/strong\u003e King focused on the \u003ca href=\"https://www.thenation.com/article/dr-martin-luther-kings-economics-through-jobs-freedom/#axzz2dI11N39W?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edemand side\u003c/a\u003e, writing “We must create full employment or we must create incomes...people must be made consumers by one method or the other.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eKing believed that no amount of economic growth in a capitalist system would ensure everyone got a job. So he wanted the government to provide every American with a guaranteed middle-class income, one that would rise with the cost of living. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBringing it to today\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWriting about King’s plan in The Atlantic in 2013, Jordan Weissmann \u003ca href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2013/08/martin-luther-kings-economic-dream-a-guaranteed-income-for-all-americans/279147/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled\u003c/a\u003e the idea of a basic income “light-years beyond the realm of mainstream political conversation today.”  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSeven light-years later, basic income has entered the mainstream political conversation, if you consider the sixth place candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination mainstream.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEntrepreneur Andrew Yang’s campaign boils down to one tweet:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://morningbrew-oslo.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/1579218403.jpg\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"300\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe candidate’s main policy proposal is the \u003ca href=\"https://freedom-dividend.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFreedom Dividend\u003c/a\u003e, a basic income of $1,000/month for every American over 18. Yang’s reasoning for UBI is very different than King’s, though. He’s primarily concerned about the mass disruption to jobs caused by AI and automation as part of the “fourth industrial revolution.”   \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo be sure, UBI has more opponents in the U.S. than supporters. I’ll list just a few of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/100137b4-0cdf-11e8-bacb-2958fde95e5e?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emajor criticisms\u003c/a\u003e here…\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt’s too expensive\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUBI would replace existing unemployment benefits and increase inequality\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBy separating work and income, it would warp social relationships\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeople would have less incentive to work\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt gives politicians a pass to sidestep tough future-of-work discussions\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://news.gallup.com/poll/267143/universal-basic-income-favored-canada-not.aspx?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGallup poll\u003c/a\u003e released last September, 43% of Americans said they supported a universal basic income program. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eUBI mini-experiments are happening all over the world, from \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/experiment-in-finland-with-guaranteed-income-creates-less-stress-but-no-jobs-11549650636?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFinland\u003c/a\u003e to \u003ca href=\"https://www.givedirectly.org/basic-income/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eKenya\u003c/a\u003e. There’s no conclusive evidence yet, and some economists say any pilot study in an advanced country is \u003ca href=\"https://www.nber.org/papers/w25538#fromrss?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edoomed to fail\u003c/a\u003e. But the fact that we’re even talking about it shows MLK’s little-known economic message is very much alive today. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\"
